name: Fluffy Ricotta Pancakes
description: Recipe video above. Ricotta pancakes are a step up from plain ones because they are extra soft and fluffy inside. Made famous by Australia's very own Bill Granger, a signature dish at his popular bistro Bills.Stove control is key, because these are thicker than standard pancakes. Heat too low, and the pancakes will be raw batter inside or won't rise enough. Too high, and the pancakes will burn before the inside is cooked. Aim for 3 minutes and golden brown surfaces. It's fine to go over (they will still be moist inside) but if you go under 2 1/2 minutes, they will be raw inside.9 - 10 pancakes (about 13cm/5" in diameter).
recipeIngredient: 3/4 cup milk ((full fat best but low fat fine))
1 tsp white vinegar ((or other clear or clear-ish vinegar, Note 2))
1/4 tsp baking soda (bi0carb) (or 3/4 tsp extra baking powder (Note 3))

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk wet - Place the Wet ingredients in a bowl and whisk vigorously to combine. You should have little ricotta curd bits in it, but you don't want giant ricotta clumps.
recipeInstructions.name: Whisk wet - Place the Wet ingredients in a bowl and whisk vigorously to combine. You should have little ricotta curd bits in it, but you don't want giant ricotta clumps.

recipeInstructions.text: Add dry - Scatter the Dry ingredients across the surface then whisk until combined. The batter is a little thicker than standard pancake batter.
recipeInstructions.name: Add dry - Scatter the Dry ingredients across the surface then whisk until combined. The batter is a little thicker than standard pancake batter.

recipeInstructions.text: Lightly butter pan - Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat until hot (I use 2 pans). Brush lightly with melted butter (or melt a bit then wipe off excess with paper towels - Note 4).
recipeInstructions.name: Lightly butter pan - Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat until hot (I use 2 pans). Brush lightly with melted butter (or melt a bit then wipe off excess with paper towels - Note 4).

recipeInstructions.text: Batter - Pour in 1/4 cup batter - it should just about spread evenly into a round but may need a bit of coaxing. (I use an ice cream scoop - Note 5)
recipeInstructions.name: Batter - Pour in 1/4 cup batter - it should just about spread evenly into a round but may need a bit of coaxing. (I use an ice cream scoop - Note 5)

recipeInstructions.text: Cook 3 minutes - Cook the first side for 1 1/2 minutes or until golden brown (turn heat down if browning too fast). Flip then cook the other side for 1 1/2 minutes or until golden. Remove onto a plate.
recipeInstructions.name: Cook 3 minutes - Cook the first side for 1 1/2 minutes or until golden brown (turn heat down if browning too fast). Flip then cook the other side for 1 1/2 minutes or until golden. Remove onto a plate.

recipeInstructions.text: Cook remaining - If your non-stick coating is good, you won't need more butter though a very light brush of melted butter every 2nd or 3rd pancake won't hurt. Continue cooking, lowering the heat as you go as the pan gets hotter. You should get 9 to 10 in total. Keep cooked pancakes stacked so they keep each other warm (or use a low 50C/125F oven).

Continue cooking, lowering the heat as you go as the pan gets hotter. You should get 9 to 10 in total. Keep cooked pancakes stacked so they keep each other warm (or use a low 50C/125F oven).

recipeInstructions.text: Serve ricotta pancakes with macerated strawberries (below), softened butter and copious amounts of maple syrup!

itemListElement.text: Toss together strawberries and sugar in a small bowl. Set aside for 20 minutes to allow them to sweat and soften slightly. (Even overnight in fridge is fine.) Serve on pancakes!

review.reviewBody: I liked you crediting Bill Granger as you have previously several times credited Martha Stewart.  Truly talented creators and artists build upon the works and culinary cultural histories/civilizations available to us all.  Truth is, I've seen a few recipe websites that have 'nicked' your work without any acknowledgement.  However, hawk-eyed foodies like me notice! :) But you Naji have strong ethics and would never do that. Thank you again for being real, amazing and bringing the joy of food and cooking to us all x
Now Nagi, I have been expertly cooking and tossing pancakes since I was 10 - these are unequivocally and absolutely the best!  Thank you and lovely to see Bill Granger given a credit too x

My advice is not to deviate from the written recipe (Nagi knows what sheâ€™s doing!) and to be patient with cooking them. We will never go back to the flat, bland pancakes of the past!

These are amazing, best pancakes I've ever made & having fed 3 generations of boys I've made a LOT! Perfectly cooked using Nagi's time. Made 13 so probably a little smaller than Nagi's. This will be top of the redo list.

I had left over ricotta after making Lasagna for Christmas. Googled to find a recipe. These pancakes were amazing and used up the rest of the ricotta I had. Pancakes were very fluffy. Served with sausage, maple syrup, and left over raspberry pie filling.
Xmas breakfast delight!  Fluffy pillows of yumminess.  Served with a sprinkling of icing sugar, butter, maple syrup and macerated strawberries.  Does not get better.
Love this recipe. Only thing I did different was spread the batter in a 12x17 pan and baked for 6 min at 400 degrees. I freeze them for a quick breakfast for my kids during the school week.

Made these for brunch this morning, and they were definitely fluffy! I got 10 from the mixture. Mine weren't so beautifully round like Nagi's, probably because I didn't use an ice-cream scoop. We had them with blueberries and maple syrup, and three was a hearty serving, though 'himself' ate 6! Next time I'll mash the ricotta with a fork first as I found it hard to get the big lumps out.
Delicious pancakes, so much better than standard pancakes!

5 stars all around!! This recipe was amaze! I always struggle with getting thick fluffy pancakes and these turned out exactly how I wanted. They were not sweet so I could put whatever I wanted on top.
Just made my 3rd batch of these in as many weeks.  The whole family loves them!  (I just cut down the sugar by 1/3rd and still works great)
I'm making these for breakfast now. My husband and children are already eating them and claiming that they are good. They are more fluffy than our usual pikelet.
They tasted really egg-y, maybe I did something wrong
